query: Why is IO Base development understaffed in week 10?
expected_answer_theme: trade-off: low understaffing cost vs higher-cost projects
reference_answer: IO Base development (d=8) has the lowest understaffing penalty in the model (0.6-0.75, linearly increasing). In week 10, the optimizer leaves 1.5 FTE of demand unmet because all available employees are allocated to projects with higher understaffing costs. Week 10 is when Foo PSO Pilot (cost 0.6-1.1) starts and overlaps with IO product demo (cost 1.3-1.1), Cmm IO Pilot (cost 1.0), and several COE projects. Forcing d_miss[10,8]=0 would require pulling employees from those higher-cost projects, increasing total objective cost. The optimizer sacrifices IO Base development (only 30.6% of demand met overall) to minimize total penalty.
grounding: d_miss[10,8]=1.5 in baseline; IO Base dev demand=1.5 FTE/week for weeks 0-23; understaffing cost [0.6,0.75] is lowest among all projects

query: Why is PSO Base development missing demand in week 15?
expected_answer_theme: trade-off: PSO Base dev lower cost than overlapping pilots
reference_answer: PSO Base development (d=0) has an understaffing cost of 0.7-0.9. In week 15, the optimizer leaves demand unmet because PSO-cohort employees (Josh, Utsav, Shivarjun, Nancy, Larry, Jason) are allocated to higher-priority PSO projects: PSO v8 migration (cost 0.95-1.0, 2.0 FTE demand), Foo PSO Pilot (cost 0.6-1.1, active weeks 10-21), and Saa PSO Pilot (cost 1.0-0.8, active weeks 12-23). Josh is the required specific employee for PSO Base dev but is spread across 4 projects. Forcing zero shortage would require pulling PSO employees from those higher-cost projects, increasing total cost. PSO Base dev is only 54.2% staffed overall.
grounding: d_miss[15,0]>0 in baseline; PSO Base dev demand=1.0 FTE/week; Josh required at 0.2 FTE; oversight required at 0.2 FTE

query: Why is Saa DF Pilot not fully staffed in week 14?
expected_answer_theme: trade-off: DF employees fully committed to higher-priority DF projects
reference_answer: Saa DF Pilot (d=21) has 1.0 FTE demand in weeks 12-23 with understaffing cost 1.0-0.8 (decreasing). In week 14, the DF-cohort employees (Yash, Bhavya, Arpit, Jason, Sruti) are fully committed to other DF projects: Nuu DF Pilot (1.5 FTE), Cmm DF Pilot (2.0 FTE), Koo DF Pilot (1.5 FTE), DF Base development (1.0 FTE), and Tyy DF COE (1.0 FTE) all overlap in weeks 12-19. With only 5 DF-cohort employees, total DF capacity cannot cover the ~8.0 FTE total DF demand in week 14. The optimizer prioritizes projects with higher or increasing understaffing costs. Saa DF Pilot is only 25% staffed overall — the worst-served pilot.
grounding: d_miss[14,21]=1.0 in baseline; Saa DF Pilot only 25% met; weeks 12-19 are peak DF crunch with 6+ FTE demand

query: Why is DF Base development understaffed in week 16?
expected_answer_theme: trade-off: base development has lower cost than overlapping DF pilots
reference_answer: DF Base development (d=14) has understaffing cost 0.8-0.75 (decreasing over time). In week 16, the optimizer prioritizes DF pilots and COE projects that have higher costs: Cmm DF Pilot (cost 1.0, 2.0 FTE), Nuu DF Pilot (cost 0.95-1.1, 1.5 FTE), Koo DF Pilot (cost 0.95-1.1, 1.5 FTE). With DF capacity of ~5.75 FTE (Yash 1.25 + Bhavya 1.25 + Arpit 1.0 + Sruti 1.25 + partial Jason) vs ~8 FTE total DF demand, DF Base development is sacrificed as the lowest-cost project. This mirrors the pattern for PSO and IO Base development. DF Base dev is only 53.1% staffed overall.
grounding: d_miss[16,14]=1.0 in baseline; DF Base dev cost [0.8,0.75] among lowest in DF cohort

query: Why is Foo PSO Pilot understaffed in week 11?
expected_answer_theme: trade-off: limited PSO capacity during peak overlap
reference_answer: Foo PSO Pilot (d=5) starts in week 10 with 1.5 FTE demand and understaffing cost 0.6-1.1 (increasing). In week 11, PSO-cohort employees are already committed: Josh on PSO Base dev + PSO v8 + PSO product demo; Larry on PSO v8 + Paa PSO + Nuu PSO COE; Nancy on PSO v8 + Foo PSO Pilot (she's the required specific employee at 0.5 FTE/week); Utsav on Nuu PSO COE (Junior, limit=1); Shivarjun on Cgg PSO COE (Junior, limit=1). Larry provides the required oversight (Lead/Manager). With Nancy partially allocated and Larry providing oversight, the remaining 1.5 FTE demand can't be fully met without pulling from higher-cost PSO projects. Foo PSO Pilot has unmet demand in weeks 10-14.
grounding: d_miss[11,5]=1.0 in baseline; Foo PSO Pilot active weeks 10-21; Nancy required at 0.5 FTE; oversight 0.2 FTE from Larry

query: Why is Saa PSO Pilot not fully staffed in week 19?
expected_answer_theme: trade-off: PSO capacity exhausted by higher-priority projects
reference_answer: Saa PSO Pilot (d=7) has 1.5 FTE demand in weeks 12-23 with cost 1.0-0.8. In week 19, d_miss=1.5 (fully unmet). The PSO employees are committed to: Josh on Saa PSO Pilot (partial) + PSO Base dev; Larry on Nuu PSO COE + Paa PSO COE; Nancy on Foo PSO Pilot (required employee); Utsav on Nuu PSO COE; Shivarjun on Cgg PSO COE. With Foo PSO Pilot still active (ends week 21) and requiring Nancy, and Juniors locked to single projects, PSO capacity is stretched thin. The decreasing cost (1.0→0.8) means the optimizer deprioritizes Saa PSO Pilot in later weeks. Overall only 58.3% of Saa PSO Pilot demand is met.
grounding: d_miss[19,7]=1.5 in baseline; Saa PSO Pilot only 58.3% met; week 19 overlaps with Foo PSO Pilot (also understaffed)

query: Why does IO Base development have unmet demand in week 20?
expected_answer_theme: trade-off: IO employees serving higher-cost IO pilots
reference_answer: IO Base development (d=8, cost 0.6-0.75) has 1.5 FTE demand in week 20. The IO-cohort employees are allocated to: Yimin on Moo IO Pilot (cost 0.95-1.1) + Koo DF Pilot (out-of-cohort); Jianchen on Moo IO Pilot + Cmm IO Pilot; Minnie on Bhh IO COE (Junior, limit=1); Stefano on IO Base dev + Cmm IO Pilot. Even with Stefano partially allocated, IO Base dev cannot be fully staffed because Moo IO Pilot (2.0 FTE, cost 0.95-1.1) and Cmm IO Pilot (1.0 FTE, cost 1.0) have higher penalties. Bhavya (DF cohort) helped earlier but is now on DF projects. IO Base dev has been consistently understaffed since week 6.
grounding: d_miss[20,8]=1.5 in baseline; IO Base dev only 30.6% met; Yimin also serving out-of-cohort on Koo DF Pilot

query: Why is Yimin idle in week 0?
expected_answer_theme: trade-off: assigning Yimin more would reduce idle but increase other costs
reference_answer: Yimin (j=5, Lead, IO cohort, FTE=1.5) is 50% idle in week 0 (x_idle[5,0]=0.5). He is partially allocated to IO product demo and Ipp IO Pilot. The optimizer doesn't fully utilize Yimin in week 0 because: (1) IO Base development demand is 1.5 FTE and has low cost (0.6), so the optimizer prefers to leave it understaffed rather than use a high-FTE Lead; (2) Assigning Yimin to more projects would increase staffing consistency cost (Obj 3) and potentially out-of-cohort penalty (Obj 4) if assigned outside IO. The idle time cost (1 unit per FTE-week) is less than the marginal cost of the fragmentation and cohort penalties that would result.
grounding: x_idle[5,0]=0.5 in baseline; Yimin is on 2 IO projects in week 0; IO Base dev has low cost [0.6,0.75]

query: Why is Sruti idle in week 3?
expected_answer_theme: trade-off: limited DF projects active early; forcing full utilization increases fragmentation
reference_answer: Sruti (j=13, Senior, DF cohort, FTE=1.25) is 20% idle in week 3 (x_idle[13,3]=0.2). In weeks 0-7, the active DF projects are: DF Base development (1.0 FTE), DF product demo (1.0 FTE), and Hee DF COE (1.25 FTE) — total 3.25 FTE demand. The DF cohort has capacity ~5.75 FTE (Yash 1.25 + Bhavya 1.25 + Arpit 1.0 + Sruti 1.25 + partial Jason 1.0). Supply exceeds demand, so some idle is inevitable. The optimizer keeps Sruti partially idle rather than assigning her to non-DF projects (which would incur out-of-cohort penalty) or splitting her across too many projects (which would increase staffing consistency cost).
grounding: x_idle[13,3]=0.2 in baseline; Sruti idle ~20% in weeks 0-6; total early DF demand < DF capacity

query: Why is Yimin idle in week 24?
expected_answer_theme: trade-off: no active projects for Yimin in week 24
reference_answer: Yimin (j=5, Lead, IO cohort) is fully idle in week 24 (x_idle[5,24]=1.0). Most IO projects have ended by week 24: Ipp IO Pilot ended at week 11, IO product demo at week 11, Cmm IO Pilot at week 23, Moo IO Pilot at week 23, IO Base development at week 23. Only Cgg PSO COE (week 0-25) and Bhh IO COE (week 0-23) extend that far, and Bhh IO COE ends at week 23. Forcing Yimin to not be idle would require assigning him to Cgg PSO COE (PSO cohort, out-of-cohort penalty) or projects with zero demand in that week. Nearly all employees are fully idle in weeks 24-25 because only 2 projects (Cgg PSO COE, Saa PSO Pilot) have any demand remaining.
grounding: x_idle[5,24]=1.0; almost all projects end by week 23; only Cgg PSO COE runs through week 25

So no one else can easily pick up Paa PSO COE without increasing fragmentation or violating concurrency limits.

query: Why is Yimin assigned to Koo DF Pilot in week 15?

reference_answer: Yimin (j=5, Lead, IO cohort) is assigned to Koo DF Pilot (d=19, DF/Pilot tags) out-of-cohort, incurring a penalty of 1.0 per the project_cohort_penalty matrix. query: Why is Bhavya working on IO Base development in week 4?

In weeks 0-8, the IO cohort has limited capacity relative to demand: IO Base dev (1.5 FTE) + IO product demo (1.5 FTE) + Ipp IO Pilot (1.5 FTE) + Bhh IO COE (1.0 FTE) = 5.5 FTE demand, but IO employees (Yimin 1.5 + Minnie 1.0 + Jianchen 1.25 + Stefano 1.25 = 5.0 FTE) can't cover it all. Meanwhile, early DF demand is only 3.25 FTE against 5.75 FTE DF capacity, so Bhavya has spare capacity. grounding: Bhavya on IO Base dev is 1 of only 2 out-of-cohort assignments; early IO demand > IO capacity; early DF demand < DF capacity

query: Why is Utsav not staffed on PSO Base development in week 5?
expected_answer_theme: max_concurrency: Utsav is a Junior (limit=1), currently on Nuu PSO COE; reassigning creates trade-off
reference_answer: Utsav (j=1, Junior, PSO cohort, max concurrent=1) is fully allocated to Nuu PSO COE (d=6) in week 5. As a Junior, he can only work on 1 project at a time (max_concurrency_constraint). Forcing x_ind[1,5,0]==1 would move Utsav from Nuu PSO COE to PSO Base development in week 5. This creates a trade-off: Nuu PSO COE (1.5 FTE demand, cost 0.95-0.85) would lose Utsav's 1.0 FTE contribution, creating shortage there, while PSO Base development (1.0 FTE demand, cost 0.7-0.9) would gain 1.0 FTE. Since Nuu PSO COE has a higher understaffing cost than PSO Base development, the optimizer keeps Utsav on Nuu PSO COE. The binding constraint is max_concurrency_constraint_{t}_{1} limiting Utsav to 1 project.
grounding: Utsav is on Nuu PSO COE for 24/26 weeks; max_concurrent=1 for Junior; Nuu PSO COE cost (0.95-0.85) > PSO Base dev cost (0.7-0.9)

query: Why is Josh not on Foo PSO Pilot in week 5?
expected_answer_theme: infeasible: Foo PSO Pilot has zero demand in week 5 (starts week 10)
reference_answer: Foo PSO Pilot (d=5) has a starting offset of 10 weeks and duration of 12 weeks, so it is only active in weeks 10-21. In week 5, the project demand is zero. Forcing x_ind[0,5,5]==1 requires x[0,5,5]>0 (due to the indicator tracking constraint x_ind<=M*x), meaning Josh must have a positive allocation to the project. However, the demand balance constraint (demand_balance_project_5_week_5) requires: sum_j x[j,5,5]*F_j + d_miss[5,5] = 0. Since all variables are non-negative, any positive allocation would make the left side positive while the right side is 0. This is a contradiction — the model is infeasible. The IIS should identify the conflict between the user constraint, the indicator tracking constraint, and the demand balance constraint.
grounding: Foo PSO Pilot: offset=10, duration=12, active weeks 10-21; demand[5,5]=0

query: Why is Nancy not working on Saa PSO Pilot in week 8?

Forcing x_ind[3,8,7]==1 requires Nancy (FTE=1.25) to have a positive allocation to a project with zero demand. The demand balance constraint (demand_balance_project_7_week_8) requires the total weighted allocation plus unmet demand to equal zero. Since all variables are non-negative and Nancy's allocation would be positive (weighted by FTE=1.25), this creates a contradiction. The IIS should contain the user constraint, indicator tracking constraint, and demand_balance_project_7_week_8.
grounding: Saa PSO Pilot: offset=12, duration=12, active weeks 12-23; demand[8,7]=0

grounding: DF product demo: offset=0, duration=8, active weeks 0-7; demand[10,15]=0

query: Why is Josh not allocated more to PSO Base development in week 12?

query: Why is Larry the one providing oversight on Foo PSO Pilot instead of Josh?
expected_answer_theme: trade-off: Josh is committed to PSO Base dev oversight; Larry provides Foo PSO Pilot oversight at minimum level
reference_answer: Foo PSO Pilot (d=5) requires oversight from a Lead or Manager (oversight_employee_constraint_5): at least 2.4 FTE-weeks (0.2*12 weeks). Larry (j=4, Manager) provides exactly the minimum 2.4 FTE-weeks — this constraint is binding. Josh (j=0, Lead) could provide oversight but is already committed to PSO Base development oversight (required specific employee at 0.2 FTE/week for 24 weeks = 4.8 FTE-weeks, and he provides 8.67). Additionally, Nancy is the required specific employee for Foo PSO Pilot at 0.5 FTE/week (specific_employee_staffing_constraint_3_5). The optimizer assigns Larry for Foo PSO Pilot oversight because Josh's capacity is more valuable on PSO Base dev + PSO v8 + Saa PSO Pilot. Forcing Josh onto Foo PSO Pilot would reduce his availability for those higher-priority commitments.
grounding: Larry provides exactly minimum oversight (2.4=2.4 FTE-weeks) on Foo PSO Pilot; Josh provides oversight on PSO Base dev; Nancy required on Foo PSO Pilot at 0.5 FTE

As a Junior, he can only work on 1 project (max_concurrency_constraint_15_2). Forcing x_ind[2,15,8]==1 (IO Base dev) would require moving Shivarjun entirely from Cgg PSO COE to IO Base dev. This trades Cgg PSO COE shortage (cost 0.8-1.0, demand=1.0) for IO Base dev coverage (cost 0.6-0.75, demand=1.5). The optimizer prefers keeping Shivarjun on the higher-cost project. Despite Shivarjun being in the IO cohort too, the cost math favors Cgg PSO COE.

query: Why is Stefano not staffed on Foo PSO Pilot in week 12?
